column16: I think the only thing that would make the study better would be a little bit more direction at the beginning of the study before we started it. column17: I would definitely prefer the presentation because it makes the breakdown of the experiment a lot more understandable. I think the presentation makes the design of the study look a lot more interesting and appealing.

column6: I think that the first part of the experiment involves coming up with a research question that is able to be tested in some way. After coming up with your research question, you'll develop a hypothesis to what you think the result of your experiment could be. Then you'll need to decide what methods you're going to use to test your theory, and actually then preform the test. During the test you'll be collecting your data and recording it. After your experiment is over you'll need to analyze what your data actually means in terms of your research question, and then draw your conclusions from that. Often, if you get results that are repeatable from your experiment the scientist will publish their work, usually in paper form. The general public as a consumer of the product of that research often doesn't see much if any of that. The only insight they might get is maybe some statistics about how the results of this study hold up against similar ones.
column8: I think the purpose of the experiment was to evaluate how easy different presentations of graphs are for people to read, to know which types are best to use when publishing studies.

column14:
*

Participation: This aspect involved active engagement in hands on work.

*

Post-study reflection: Reflection allowed for the students perspective and critical analysis of the project experience. 

*

Extended abstract: The extended abstract served as a summary of the project, highlighting key aspects such as objectives, and conclusions.

*

Presentation: The presentation offered an opportunity to communicate project findings to a wider audience in a written format.

It offers an overview of the study's methodology and findings, providing the necessary information to assess the experiment's design and execution.

column6: I think scientific investigations present themselves differently from the perspective of a researcher vs. the consumer of the results. This is because when you are the researcher, you have formed the question, and came up with the incidentals for how a case will be tested/ received. However, I find myself, as a consumer of scientific results in class, questioning the researcher, and asking questions that could allow for improvement. I believe this is because I, myself did not have to worry about actually conducting the case, so the "what-if," and improvements didn't actually have to be implemented. With that being said, I think the major difference is that a researcher tries to make an investigation as simple as possible, whereas it is easy for an observer to try and overcomplicate the investigation, which can lead to further investigations built off the original findings.

column6: I think consumers of studies are often not privy to the need for close consideration of the sample from which studies are taken. The researchers know to clarify that results indicate things only about the things close to the sample from which data were extracted, but a lack of close reading or hyperbolic presentation of findings by third parties leads to consumers coming away with exaggerated or untrue conclusions.
column8: The purpose of the experiment was to catalogue how accurately people are able to read graphical representations of data depending on the medium in which this data is presented (digital 2D, digital 3D, digital 3D interactive, and real life 3D)
column9: The experimenter may have been testing the hypothesis that individuals can more accurately interpret graphical representations of data through 3D models than they can with 2D representations.
column10: One source of error could be the differences in screen size and formatting between study participants introducing an extra degree of variability in their ability to interpret graphs. Small errors in the 3D printing of sample kits used by study participants could also introduce variability that skews results.
column11: The variables that were examined were which bar a study participant claimed was smaller, which was categorical, as well as the degree to which they claimed it was smaller, which was quantitative.
column12: Randomization of which kit study participants selected was present. This randomization allows finding to be extrapolated to a variety of 3D graphs rather than just the specific set that any given participant is given.
column13: The reasoning for the experiment being conducted is more clear now. It seems there have been studies that have claimed 3D graphs are less effective at conveying data to observers, but this study seeks to challenge those results by presenting 3D graphs in interactable mediums that more closely resemble how humans would normally encounter 3D objects to see if 3D representations are truly less effective or if they are simply ineffective when presented from a fixed perspective on 2D screens. One question I would have for the researcher is if they believe the interactable 3D visualizations provided digitally will be any more effective than non interactable digital 3D visualizations, as I suspect they will be at most equally as ineffective if not more so due to the complexities of interacting with 3D objects through a 2D screen.
column14: Aspects such as the history of 3D graphics and the fact that studies have show them to be somewhat less effective at conveying information about data than 2D graphics were left out of the initial debrief we received as participants. This is likely because any information such as this being provided at the outset could skew participants' perception of material in the study and lead to a compromise in the data they produce.
column15: The presentation made the purpose of the study and what it aimed to do in challenging the results of studies that had shown that 3D modes of data presentation are ineffective much more clear. It is important to obscure some of this information at the outset in order to prevent introducing bias into the minds of participants. The abstract serves to present the information participants need in order to play a role in the study in the most neutral fashion as to not introduce extra variables to the study that would confound the results it produces.
column16: The digital portion of the study, particular manipulating the 3D graphics on a screen as well as interacting with the sliders used to log perceived size of the bars was somewhat clunky to interact with. column17: The presentation made me feel more interested in the study and invested in it's goals, however the abstract is likely a better show of the study as it should be presented to participants and various other viewers in order to prevent introducing bias caused by too much inside information regarding how the efficacy of 3D graphics has been assessed in the past.

column6: From the perspective of a researcher, the process of scientific investigation is an intricate process. It begins with identifying a question or problem, followed by thorough research and coming up with a hypotheses. Researchers then design experiments or observational studies to test these hypotheses, they also collect and analyzing data. Peer review and replication steps are taken to ensure reliability. But from the perspective of someone in the general public viewing scientific results, the process may appear more straightforward. They might not see all the steps and might think it juts comes from a simple and quick experiment.

column6: From a researcher's perspective, they themselves ask the question, design the experiment, conduct the experiment, gather data, observe the results, and draw conclusions. They have a lot of control over the experiment. Observers, however, do not have control over the experiment and instead can only see the data/results. They do not participate in the experimental design or conduction of the experiment. Both parties are involved in observing the results and drawing conclusions. There are benefits to drawing conclusions for each group. The researcher will likely have a better understanding of the entire study because they designed the whole thing, however, they could have a possible bias if they want to see a specific result. An observer may not have as good an understanding, however, they are more likely to be unbiased to the results.

column6: For a researcher, a question regarding something will institute some form of an investigation. This investigation will hopefully allow them to better understand how or why something works in a certain way. After the researcher has completed an investigation, a consumer of scientific readings can use it. Someone of the general public could have a similar question to the research without the ability to perform an investigation. However, since a researcher has already done an investigation and shared their findings, the consumer can use that information to help them understand their question.

column6: From the perspective of a researcher, the process of scientific investigation is a rigorous and systematic journey of inquiry and discovery. This process is iterative, with researchers revising and refining their hypotheses and methods based on the data and insights gained. Ultimately, the findings are shared with the scientific community through peer-reviewed publications, contributing to the collective body of knowledge and informing future research. On the other hand, from the perspective of someone in the general public who is a consumer of scientific results, the process may appear more straightforward and linear. Consumers often encounter science as a series of established facts and conclusions presented in news articles, documentaries, or educational materials.

column6: Creating hypotheses, carrying out tests, evaluating data, and coming to conclusions based on supporting evidence are all part of scientific investigation. Researchers adhere to strict procedures and frequently work together with other researchers to guarantee the accuracy and consistency of their discoveries. Public consumption of scientific data frequently involves coming across discoveries through media sources, which have a tendency to sensationalize or oversimplify intricate study findings. This may cause a disconnect between the public's understanding of scientific certainty and the process's complexity.

column6: From the perspective of a researcher, science is a process that starts with curiosity and then continues with experimentation and collaboration. It begins with identifying a question or problem, followed through with research to understand existing knowledge and gaps. Researchers design experiments, collect data, analyze results, and draw conclusions, often revising hypotheses along the way based on how experiments go. In contrast, for the general public, consuming scientific results might appear as a more straightforward process, with findings presented through media or other publications. Making the general public think that science is a series of definitive discoveries rather than an ongoing understanding.
